article.title: Magnetization dynamics of weakly interacting sub-100 nm square artificial spin ices

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following statements about the magnetization dynamics of the square artificial spin ice (ASI) shown in Figure 1 is INCORRECT?
choices: Panel (d) shows the magnetization state of the ASI when a saturating field is applied.
Panel (e) shows an intermediate magnetization state where monopolar charges are created due to individual flips of nanomagnets.
The yellow and green dots in Panel (e) represent positive and negative monopolar charges, respectively.
Panel (f) shows the initial magnetization state of the ASI, before the saturating field is applied.

multiple_choice_question.text: What trend is observed in the average blocking temperature (TB) of the square ASI samples with respect to the lattice spacing?
choices: The average TB increases with increasing lattice spacing.
The average TB decreases with increasing lattice spacing.
The average TB is independent of the lattice spacing.
The trend cannot be determined from the figure.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the inverse correlation observed between the average TB and the interaction strength in both the experimental and simulated square ASIs?
choices: It indicates that the samples are in a strongly interacting regime.
It confirms that the Monte Carlo simulation method is not suitable for studying these systems.
It suggests that the samples are in a weakly interacting regime, as predicted by the theory of Shtrikman and Wohlfarth.
It highlights the negligible role of dipolar interactions in these systems.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the stretching exponent (β), extracted from the stretched exponential fits to the magnetization relaxation data, reveal about the magnetization dynamics in the square ASIs?
choices: A β value of 1/3 suggests three-dimensional magnetization dynamics processes.
A β value of 1/2 corresponds to two-dimensional magnetization dynamics processes.
The observed decrease in β for higher temperatures indicates an increase in the dimensionality of the thermal excitations.
The stretching exponent is not related to the dimensionality of the magnetization dynamics processes.
